results.title: How the U.S. Hid an Airstrike That Killed Dozens of Civilians in Syria
results.abstract: The military never conducted an independent investigation into a 2019 bombing on the last bastion of the Islamic State, despite concerns about a secretive commando force.
results.byline: By Dave Philipps and Eric Schmitt
des_facet: United States Defense and Military Forces
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
org_facet: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

multimedia.caption: Fleeing heavy bombardment in Baghuz, Syria — the Islamic State’s last holdout — on March 18, 2019.

results.title: Times Investigation: In U.S. Drone Strike, Evidence Suggests No ISIS Bomb
results.abstract: U.S. officials said a Reaper drone followed a car for hours and then fired based on evidence it was carrying explosives. But in-depth video analysis and interviews at the site cast doubt on that account.
results.byline: By Matthieu Aikins, Christoph Koettl, Evan Hill and Eric Schmitt
des_facet: United States Defense and Military Forces

multimedia.copyright: By The New York Times. Video frame: Nutrition & Education International.

results.title: Can Self-Defense Laws Stand Up to a Country Awash in Guns?
results.abstract: The Kyle Rittenhouse and Ahmaud Arbery cases raise intriguing legal questions about people who take the law into their own hands and then claim self-defense when someone dies.

multimedia.caption: A detective holding the gun used by Kyle Rittenhouse last year.

results.title: Migrants Say Belarusians Took Them to E.U. Border and Supplied Wire Cutters
results.abstract: Iraqi Kurds and other migrants said they were fleeing despair at home, but Belarus encouraged them, offering visas and helping them get to the border.
results.byline: By Jane Arraf and Elian Peltier
des_facet: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

multimedia.caption: Kamyar and Sarhang, second and third from left, were joined by friends as they picked up their visas for Belarus on Thursday at a travel agency in Sulaimaniya, Iraq.
multimedia.copyright: Laura Boushnak for The New York Times

results.title: Menace Enters the Republican Mainstream
results.abstract: Threats of violence have become commonplace among a significant part of the party, as historians and those who study democracy warn of a dark shift in American politics.
results.byline: By Lisa Lerer and Astead W. Herndon

multimedia.caption: Rioters at the Capitol on Jan. 6. Polling suggests that 30 percent of Republicans believe that “true patriots” may have to resort to violence to “save” the country.
multimedia.copyright: Jason Andrew for The New York Times

results.title: Chris Christie Wants the Post-Trump G.O.P. to Move Past 2020
results.abstract: In a new book and in an interview, Mr. Christie says that if the former president wants to be a positive force, “he’s got to let this other stuff go.”
des_facet: Republican Rescue: Saving the Party From Truth Deniers, Conspiracy Theorists, and the Dangerous Policies of Joe Biden (Book)

multimedia.caption: Chris Christie says his new book is not about Donald J. Trump, but “about where we go from here and why it is important for us to let go of the past.”
multimedia.copyright: Al Drago for The New York Times

results.title: ‘They See Us as the Enemy’: School Nurses Battle Covid-19, and Angry Parents
results.abstract: School nurses, who were already stretched thin before the pandemic, say that they are overworked and overwhelmed.

multimedia.copyright: Brandon Thibodeaux for The New York Times

results.title: The Thrilling Dare of Scorched Rice
results.abstract: When browned on the bottom of the pot by a skilled cook, the grain is transformed into a complex delicacy, one prized by food cultures around the world.
results.byline: By Ligaya Mishan and Anthony Cotsifas

multimedia.caption: A stack of nurungji, Korean scorched rice.
multimedia.copyright: Photograph by Anthony Cotsifas. Food styling by Young Gun Lee. Set design by Suzy Kim

results.title: Tracing Mexico’s Complicated Relationship With Rice
results.abstract: Having arrived in the country via the Spanish Conquest, the grain’s presence poses the question: What’s native, and what isn’t, when it comes to a nation’s culinary history?
results.byline: By Aatish Taseer and Stefan Ruiz

multimedia.caption: The vendor and cook Doña Vale sits at her stall in the Mercado de Abastos, one of the oldest and most popular street markets in Oaxaca, enjoying a bit of chocolate and bread after a morning of work.

results.title: In Senegal, a Return to Homegrown Rice
results.abstract: The country has remained mostly dependent on the grain’s importation since colonization in the 1800s. But some locals are trying to change that.
results.byline: By Angela Flournoy and Manuel Obadia-Wills

multimedia.caption: At Phare Des Mamelles, a restaurant in a lighthouse in Dakar, Senegal, grilled thiof (a white grouper fish) is served with cups of tamarind sauce (left), sauce moyo (right), roasted vegetables, limes and riz de la vallée (“rice of the valley”), which is grown in one of the country’s primary areas of cultivation, the Senegal River Valley. Beside the dish are some of its raw ingredients, including (clockwise from bottom) tamarind fruits, tomatoes, a bowl of dried peppers, fresh pepper fruits, onions, miniature eggplants, miniature green bell peppers, baby carrots and potatoes.

results.title: For Many Members of the Arab American Diaspora, Mansaf Offers a Taste of Home
results.abstract: The traditional Bedouin dish of bread, rice, lamb and yogurt is a talisman of identity in Jordan — and in various communities in suburban Detroit.
results.byline: By Diana Abu-Jaber and Renee Cox

multimedia.caption: A home-cooked mansaf of bread, rice, lamb and yogurt made by the Bazzi family, who own the Dearborn institution Habib’s Cuisine.

results.title: Steven Mark Klein, Fashion Archivist and Gadfly, Dies at 70

results.title: What Does It Take to Build a Disaster-Proof House?
results.abstract: A few homeowners across the country are trying to find out, by experimenting with new (and old) construction techniques.

multimedia.caption: After the 2018 Camp Fire destroyed Mike and Jennifer Petersen’s home in Paradise, Calif., they decided to replace it with a Q Cabin, a 1,400-square-foot structure made from noncombustible steel. “If there is going to be something that could survive a fire,” Mr. Petersen said, “this would be it.”
multimedia.copyright: Jason Henry for The New York Times

results.title: Flooding and Nuclear Waste Eat Away at a Tribe’s Ancestral Home
results.abstract: The federal government allowed a stockpile of spent fuel on a Minnesota reservation to balloon even as a dam project whittled down the amount of livable land.

multimedia.copyright: Laylah Amatullah Barrayn for The New York Times

results.title: Urbanites Flock to Atlantic Canada as Pandemic Blunts Cities’ Appeal
results.abstract: As housing prices soar in big cities, the country’s eastern provinces are experiencing a surge in migration. Newcomers are being welcomed, but some locals are wary.

results.title: India Wants to Send Wheat to Ease Afghan Hunger Crisis. Pakistan Has Yet to OK Transit.
results.abstract: Indian officials say Islamabad is dragging its feet on a request of transit for 50,000 tons of wheat to Afghanistan, where nine million people are on the brink of starvation.

multimedia.caption: Loading grain onto a truck in February in Amritsar, in the northwestern Indian state of Punjab, near the border with Pakistan.

results.title: Bannon Indicted on Contempt Charges Over House’s Capitol Riot Inquiry

results.title: Deere Reaches Third Tentative Deal With Union in Attempt to End Strike

results.title: Doctor Charged With False Report to Summon Helicopter on Denali

multimedia.caption: Denali park rangers warned they had seen “a disturbing amount of overconfidence paired with inexperience” in the first month of the mountain’s 2021 climbing season.

results.title: Lawyer for Man Accused of Killing Ahmaud Arbery Draws Scrutiny

results.title: Sudanese Security Forces Fire on Protesters as Military Tightens Grip

results.title: Helene Fortunoff, Who Built a Family Jewelry Empire, Dies at 88
results.abstract: A powerhouse female executive in a male-dominated industry, she hired a team of mostly women buyers who traveled the world to find unusual gems.

results.title: He Stalks Delirious, Unfinished New York as It Rises
results.abstract: Nick Relph’s new book, “Eclipse Body & Soul Syntax,” collects years of digital street scans of New York City construction posters, an eerie portrait of a supersizing metropolis.

results.title: Barbara Kruger: Infinitely Copied, Still Unmatched
